comments.commentBody: Bloomberg's money got the right democrat elected in the Illinois special election to replace Rep. Jesse Jackson. There was another candidate, also a democrat, who before he got involved, had the lead. His support made all the difference and she was defeated.

Democrats would need to be in the majority for gun control legislation even to be brought up for a vote and they would need a super majority to block a filibuster. So, Bloomberg's campaign against four Democrats makes sense, how?

There are several Republicans in states President Obama won who voted against background checks:
Ayotte (NH), Johnson (W), Portman (OH), Rubio (FL), Heller (NV), Grassley (IA).

Target them, Mr. Mayor. We need less Senate Republicans, not more.
A Republican Senate majority would insure gun control legislation would never see the light of day.

Begich, Pryor & Heikamp do not share my political values but they stand in the way of a Republican Senate majority that would stand in direct opposition to gun control, a minimum wage increase, affordable health care, science, the social safety net and everything else I do value.

In my ideal political world the Senate would be controlled by progressive Democrats. No chance that will happen in the near future, certainly not by 2014 but the Republicans do have a real chance of taking back the Senate, a disasterous outcome, as far as I'm concerned.

If Mr. Bloomberg really wants to target some Senators, he'd serve the country and his signature issue far better by starting with McConnell and finishing up with Grassley, Ayotte, Heller, Johnson, Portman & Rubio.

Better yet, take your money and go home.

Speaking as a professional electrician, if you have 40+ year old fixtures in various states of repair, you ought to replace them all anyways as they're a fire hazard. Unless they're all basic incandescent sockets, in which case it's time to switch to LED bulbs and start saving more electricity.

Either way, "I'm using ancient and crappy items, but replacing them is hard" isn't an excuse. We don't allow leaded gas to be sold anymore despite the need to replace old cars that results.

Alex, the steel and copper in the fixtures will be recycled, the fluorescent tubes will be recycled. Toxic oils potentially contain cancer-causing PCB will be recycled instead of leaking into your office or being thrown in the trash one at a time. These would only "go to the landfill" if someone was willing to commit a crime. If these 1000+ fixtures are really 40 years old, they must have a horrible productivity-depressing effect on the people who work there. New fixtures distribute light so much more efficiently, it's frequently possible to reduce the number of fixtures due to efficient optics.

Studies have shown improved attendance, safety, and morale accompany lighting overhauls. There's a goldmine on those ceilings!
All the light bulbs developed and proposed work in current fixtures.  There is no need to change fixtures, just to change bulbs.

Go ahead, tell me how environmentally friendly it is going to be when my office rips out 1,000+ light fixtures because we can no longer get bulbs for them or bulbs are in short supply due to looming bans.

They're all heading for the landfill. All 1,000+ of them. It's cheaper for us to rip out the old ones & replace them with new fixtures rather than attempting to retrofit 40+ year old fixtures in various states of repair.

Think of the damage from that, not to mention the pollution involved with making new fixtures, transporting those new fixtures, and also hauling away the old ones. The actual electricity used is only PART of the equation. Similarly, hybrid vehicles, at least passenger ones, have a worse impact on the earth due to the manufacturing of their batteries than they'll ever save in reduced petroleum emissions.

I wish these busybodies would look at the FULL impact of their proposals. Everyone wants to save money. Let's be reasonable about it.

It is so disheartening to not see the president fighting with all his abilities to push through regulations that will limit the greenhouse gases we pump into the atmosphere. In the early days after first becoming president, with great efficiency and leadership he led the way towards mandating that cars and trucks get more miles per gallon of gas. As an advocate of environmentalism, I was overjoyed at this long overdue accomplishment. I felt that other necessary changes that most climate scientists believe will be needed to combat global warming might be set in motion as well by our new president. The feeling of hope I felt at that time was palpable.

So to be at a point where the reviews that are needed to enact other important efficiency standards for our power plants and appliances are now double the average over the last 15 years (as stated by Mr. Copeland in this article), I sense President Obama trying to placate people who simply deny any urgency around Environmental Protection of any kind.

In my view, Obama has nothing to lose by strongly fighting for the U.S. being a leader in all actions that will curb our current CO2 emissions. For this, he would be remembered as a pivotal enactor of positive change, and not simply another follower who didn't fight hard enough against the corporate forces that would choose to do nothing.

They won't solve all the problems with gun violence but isn't doing something better than doing nothing?

Most people who buy the guns that are eventually used for violence aren't overtly criminal or crazy. And an episode of depression, say, shouldn't disqualify someone from ever going out hunting during deer season.

The real solution is to have vastly fewer guns, especially handguns and assault weapons. The idea that a "background" check can filter out the potentially criminal and the careless is just a fantasy, and I'm surprised a hard-nosed businessman like Mike is behind it.

"Do men now have less reproductive autonomy than women?" Here's an example going the other direction.

Recently, a study went viral declaring that men are more likely to sabotage birth control than women. It identified a reported rate of "reproductive coercion" of 16% among men, and compared that to an earlier 2010 study that showed only 8.7% of men reported equivalent acts of women sabotaging birth control. The gist of the viral sharing was "men try to control women by sabotaging birth control more than women do."

But this was misrepresentation. When you break into the data, "reproductive coercion" isn't just birth-control sabotage, but also social pressuring women to have children. On the screening questionnaire, women were also asked if their partner ever 'threatened' to end their relationship to seek a partner willing to have children. This was counted equivalent to birth-control sabotage in the 16% headline number; when you reduce reproductive coercion to birth-control sabotage, the study showed an incident rate of 9.2%, within the margin of error of 8.7%.

Nevermind that "men sabotage birth control more than women" has become an untrue trope; consider the straightforward acceptance of the idea that men shouldn't say they may end a relationship because they want to have children while their current partner does not. Why on earth is that condemned as equivalent to birth-control sabotage? Shouldn't men be free to seek partners with the same family-goals as them?
